abstract.t: This document specifies the BIER Multicast Listener Discovery (BMLD) Protocol, which adapts the Multicast Listener Discovery protocol version 2 (MLDv2) to be used over BIER, enabling state sharing from egress routers, acting as listeners, toward ingress routers, acting as queriers. Ingress routers keep per-egress-router multicast subscription state, used to construct the BIER bit mask inserted to multicast packets entering the BIER domain.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Bit Index Explicit Replication (BIER) forwarding scheme enables multicast forwarding within a BIER domain. When receiving or generating a packet, ingress routers have to construct a bit mask indicating which BIER egress routers located within the same BIER domain will receive the packet. A stateless approach would consist in forwarding all incoming packets toward all egress routers, which would in turn make a forwarding decision based on local information. But any more efficient approach would require ingress routers to keep some state about egress routers multicast subscriptions, hence requiring state sharing from egress routers toward ingress routers.

State sharing techniques inspired from existing multicast routing protocols such as PIMv2 would require intermediate routers to keep subscription states, which is undesirable as BIER does not need such state on intermediate routers. On the other hand, the Multicast Listener Discovery protocol version 2 is widely available and has multiple interoperable implementations, but is only able to share multicast subscription state between routers and hosts connected on the same link.

This document specifies the BIER Multicast Listener Discovery (BMLD) Protocol, which adapts the Multicast Listener Discovery protocol version 2 (MLDv2) to be used over BIER, enabling state sharing from egress routers, acting as listeners, toward ingress routers, acting as queriers. Ingress routers keep per-egress-router multicast subscription state, used to construct the BIER bit mask inserted to multicast packets entering the BIER domain.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: In this document, the key words "MAY", "MUST", "MUST NOT", "RECOMMENDED", and "SHOULD", are to be interpreted as described in .
The terms "Bit-Forwarding Router" (BFR), "Bit-Forwarding Egress Router" (BFER), "Bit-Forwarding Ingress Router" (BFIR), "BFR-id" and "BFR-Prefix" are to be interprated as described in .

Additionaly, the following definitions are used:
The BIER Multicast Listener Discovery Protocol. A BFIR implementing the Querier part of the BMLD protocol. As a BMLD Querier receives BMLD messages, it also is a BFER. A BMLD Node MAY be both a Querier and a Listener. A BFER implementing the Listener part of the BMLD protocol. A a BMLD Listener sends BMLD messages, it also is a BFIR. A BMLD Node MAY be both a Querier and a Listener.

section.title: Overview
section.t: This document proposes to use the mechanisms described in MLDv2 in order to enable multicast subscription state sharing from BFERs toward BFIRs within a given BIER domain. BMLD queries (resp. reports) are sent over BIER toward all BMLD Nodes (resp. BMLD Queriers) using modified MLDv2 messages which IPv6 destination is set to a configured 'all BMLD Nodes' (resp. 'all BMLD Queriers') IPv6 multicast address.

By running MLDv2 instances with per-listener explicit tracking, BMLD Queriers are able to map BMLD Listeners (The BFR-Prefix is used as source address in all BMLD reports) with MLDv2 subscription states. This state is then used to construct the set of BFERs for each incoming IPv6 multicast data packet.

section.title: Applicability Statement
section.t: The BMLD protocol runs on top of a BIER Layer and provides the BFIR part of the services provided by a Multicast Flow Overlay (The BIER layering architecture is described in ), i.e, it specifies how BFIRs construct the set of BFERs for each ingress IPv6 multicast data packet. The BFER part of the Multicast Flow Overlay is out of scope of this document.

The BIER Layer MUST be able to transport BMLD messages toward all BMLD Queriers and Listeners. Such packets are IPv6 multicast packets with a BFR-id as source address, a multicast destination address, and containing a MLDv2 message.

The BMLD protocol only requires state to be kept by Queriers, and is therefore more scalable in terms of overall state, but is also likely to be less scalable than PIMv2 in terms of the amount of control traffic and the size of the state that is kept by individual routers.
The whole protocol can be adapted to IPv4 multicast, as specified in .

section.title: Querier and Listener Specifications
section.t: Routers desiring to receive IPv6 multicast traffic (e.g., for their own use, or for forwarding) MUST behave as BMLD Listeners. Routers receiving IPv6 multicast traffic from outside the BIER domain, or locally generating multicast traffic, MUST behave as BMLD Queriers.
BMLD Queriers (resp. BMLD Listeners) MUST act as MLDv2 Queriers (resp. MLDv2 Listeners) as specified in unless stated otherwise in this section.

section.title: Configuration Parameters
section.t: Both Queriers and Listeners MUST be able to operate as BFIRs and BFERs within the BIER domain, and MUST therefore be configured accordingly, as specified in .
All Listeners MUST be configured with a 'all BMLD Queriers' multicast address and the BFR-ids of all the BMLD Queriers. This is used by Listeners to send BMLD Reports over BIER toward all Queriers.

All Queriers MUST be configured with a 'all BMLD Nodes' multicast address and the BFR-ids of all the Queriers and Listeners. This information is used by Queriers to send BMLD queries over BIER toward all BMLD Nodes.

Note that BMLD (unlike MLDv2) makes use of per-instance configured multicast group addresses rather than well-known addresses so that multiple instances of BMLD (using different group addresses) can be run simultaneously within the same BIER domain. Configured group addresses MAY be obtained from allocated IPv6 prefixes using .

IPv6 packets coming from outside of the BIER domain and having a destination address set to the configured 'all BMLD Queriers' or the 'all BMLD Nodes' group address MUST be dropped. It is RECOMMENDED that these configured addresses have a limited scope, enforcing this behavior by scope-based filtering on BIER domain's egress interfaces.

section.title: MLDv2 instances.
section.t: BMLD Queriers MUST run a MLDv2 Querier instance with per-host tracking, which means they keep track of the MLDv2 state associated with each BMLD Listener. For that purpose, Listeners are identified by their respective BFR-Prefixes, used as IPv6 source address in all BMLD reports.
BMLD Listeners MUST run a MLDv2 Listener instance expressing their interest in the multicast traffic they are supposed to receive for local use or forwarding.
BMLD Listeners and Queriers MUST NOT run the MLDv1 backward compatibility procedures.

section.title: Sending Queries
section.t:
BMLD Queries are IPv6 packets sent over BIER by BMLD Queriers:
Toward all BMLD Nodes (i.e., providing to the BIER Layer the BFR-ids of all BMLD Nodes). Without the router alert option in the hop-by-hop extension header . With the IPv6 destination address set to the 'all BMLD Nodes' group address. With the IPv6 source address set to the BFR-Prefix of the sender. With a TTL value great enough such that the packet can be received by all BMLD Nodes, depending on the underlying BIER layer (whether it decrements the IPv6 TTL or not) and the size of the network. The default value is 64.

section.title: Sending Reports
section.t:
BMLD Reports are IPv6 packets sent over BIER by BMLD Listeners:
Toward all BMLD Queriers (i.e., providing to the BIER layer the BFR-ids of all BMLD Queriers). Without the router alert option in the hop-by-hop extension header. With the IPv6 destination address set to the 'all BMLD Queriers' group address. With the IPv6 source address set to the BFR-Prefix of the sender. With a TTL value great enough such that the packet can be received by all BMLD Queriers, depending on the underlying BIER layer (whether it decrements the IPv6 TTL or not) and the size of the network. The default value is 64.

section.title: Receiving Queries
section.t: BMLD Queriers and Listeners MUST check the destination address of all the IPv6 packets that are received or forwarded over BIER whenever their own BIER bit is set in the packet. If the destination address is equal to the 'all BMLD Nodes' the packet is processed as specified in this section.
If the IPv6 packet contains an ICMPv6 message of type 'Multicast Listener Query', it is processed by the MLDv2 instance run by the BMLD Querier. It MUST be dropped otherwise.

During the MLDv2 processing, the packet MUST NOT be checked against the MLDv2 consistency conditions (i.e., the presence of the router alert option, the source address being link-local and the TTL equaling 1).

section.title: Receiving Reports
section.t: BMLD Queriers MUST check the destination address of all the IPv6 packets that are received or forwarded over BIER whenever their own BIER bit is set. If the destination address is equal to the 'all BMLD Queriers' the packet is processed as specified in this section.
If the IPv6 packet contains an ICMPv6 message of type 'Multicast Listener Report Message v2', it is processed by the MLDv2 instance run by the BMLD Querier. It MUST be dropped otherwise.

During the MLDv2 processing, the packet MUST NOT be checked against the MLDv2 consistency conditions (i.e., the presence of the router alert option, the source address being link-local and the TTL equaling 1).

section.title: Packet Forwarding
section.t: BMLD Queriers configure the BIER Layer using the information obtained using the BMLD protocol which associates BMLD Listeners (identified by their BFR-Prefixes) with their respective MLDv2 subscription state.

More specifically, the MLDv2 state associated with each BMLD Listener is provided to the BIER layer such that whenever a multicast packet enters the BIER domain, if that packet matches the subscription state from a BMLD Listener, its BFR-id is added to the set of BFR-ids the packet should be forwarded to by the BIER-Layer.

section.title: Legacy IP Support
section.t:
The present specification may be applied to IPv4 by either:
Substituting MLDv2 by IGMPv3 in the present document and replacing IPv6 unicast or multicast addresses by IPv4 addresses. Encoding IPv4 addresses into MLDv2 messages as IPv6-mapped IPv4 addresses .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The protocol specified in this document makes use of IPv6 MLDv2 messages transported over BIER in order to configure the BIER Layer of BFIRs. BMLD messages MUST be secured, either by relying on physical or link-layer security, or by securing the IPv6 packets (e.g., using IPSec ).

Whenever an attacker would be able to spoof the identity of a router, it could:
Redirect undesired traffic toward the spoofed router by subscribing to undesired multicast traffic. Prevent desired multicast traffic from reaching the spoofed router by unsubscribing to some desired multicast traffic.
